data.title: General book recommendations!
data.meta_description:
Hey composer friends.

I have a question for you.

For a while now, I've been not as inspired by current tv shows or movies. I used to be very inspired...
data.text:
Some really great literature in this thread! I will add a few, my apologies if I repeat any.

Dan Simmons - Illium/Olympos, in addition to the Hyperion Cantos (sentient robots discussing Shakespearean sonnets while traveling to check out disturbances on Mars, and a recreation of the Trojan War, on Mars, come on!) and honestly everything else he has written, The Terror, Carrion Comfort, etc.

Herman Hesse - anything he wrote

Phillip K Dick - again can't go wrong - a little out there but nothing like Joyce's Ulysses

Patrick O'Brian - The Aubrey/Maturin Novels (English Navy/ Spy novels during the late Napoleonic Era, you will absolutely develop an attachment to the idea of English puddings, I made my first Spotted Dog about 15 years ago)

Peter F. Hamilton - start with the Night's Dawn Trilogy and move forward, very excellent edge of your seat reading, sci-fi

Neal Stephenson -Cryptonomicon, The Baroque Cycle

Alexandre Dumas - The Count of Monte Cristo

Umberto Eco - Everything I have read, I have immensely enjoyed

Charles Stross - The Merchant Princes series and The Laundry Files

Jim Butcher - The Dresden Files

Aldous Huxley - Ape and Essence and all others

Joseph Campbell - all of his books - mostly dealing with mythology

Christopher Moore - for books that will wreck you with laughter (not for the faint of heart)

Arthur Conan Doyle - Sherlock Holmes series

James Joyce

Robert Anton Wilson - for a ride from which your brain may not ever be the same again.

+1 on Leo Tolstoy, Terry Pratchett, George RR Martin, Iain Banks, William Gibson, Mark Twain, Vonnegut, Anton Chekhov

I love books!!!

Hell of a list
